Put 1/4 pint of the warm fluid into a porcelain dish, skim off all fat, let it get cold and put on the sliced pickles and a few tablespoons of broth, let it cool, arrange the chicken meat on it in the form of scales, pour the rest of the broth on and let it get cold and stiff. Then turn it out on a platter and garnish with parsley. Asparagus cut into small pieces may also be used in this gelatin.
5f6ba118-60d8-4300-bf1c-b1886e00050d Boil vegetables in 3-4 parts of water for 20 minutes. Drain vegetables and add the liquid to meats. Cook all meats in a little water at 80° C (176° F) until soft. Separate from bones when the meat is still warm. In home production meat is usually not ground. Save meat stock for aspic. Mix all ingredients together adding some meat stock. Stuff into 100 mm (4”) artificial waterproof casings (presswurst was traditionally stuffed in pork stomachs).
5f6ba118-60d8-4300-bf1c-b1886e00050d Cook in water at 80° C (176° F) for about 2 hours. Immerse in cold water for 15 minutes. Place on flat surface and stack sausages one on top of the other. Turn around every hour or so to prevent heavier ingredient settling in one area. When sufficiently cold place sausage in refrigerator.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Place all meats in a suitable pot, add leek, celery, parsnip, carrot, onion, peppercorns and cover with 1 inch of water and wine. Bring to a boil and simmer below boiling point until meats are soft and the bones are easily removable.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Drain the meats, spread on the table and allow to cool. Save meat stock, discard vegetables.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 When the meats are still warm, separate the meat from the bones. Cut larger chunks into smaller pieces, cut the skins into strips.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Mix meats with salt, garlic, oregano, cayenne adding about 1/2 cup (125 ml) of the meat stock. This meat stock is a naturally produced gelatin.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Using a ladle stuff the mixture loosely into pork stomachs or large diameter synthetic casings.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Cook in water at 80° C (176° F) for 90-120 min (depending on the size) until meat reaches 68-70° C (154-158° F) internal temperature.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let the steam out. Flatten with weight and cool to 6° C (43° F) or lower.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface and cut off excess twine.
bfb5ed5e-2a00-455e-9d1c-e77e2f5db261 Keep refrigerated.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Creating meat stock (gelatin). Immerse meats in pot, add soup greens, bay leaves and whole black peppers and cover with 5 cm (2") of water. Bring to a boil and simmer for 2-3 until the meat can be separated from bones. If water level drops too much add a little water. Drain the meats and spread on the table to cool. Save the meat stock as this will become the natural gelatin that will hold meats together. Place meat stock in refrigerator. When the meat is still warm but comfortable to work with, separate all meats including snouts, ears, and skins from the bones. If the split heads come with tongue, use it as well. Cut all meats into smaller parts. Recover meat stock from refrigerator and discard any fat from the surface. Add salt, diced garlic, cumin, oregano and aji source to meat stock until you are satisfied with the result.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Mixing. Start mixing meats gradually adding meat stock. Add some vinegar to taste, this is optional as most people eat head cheese with lemon or vinegar. You cannot spoil the product by adding not enough or too much of the meat stock. Adding more of the stock will produce head cheese with more gelatin, a kind of meat jelly. Some people like more jelly, some like less.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Stuffing. Fill pork stomach or a large diameter synthetic casing with the mixture. It is usually done with a ladle.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Cooking. Cook in water at 80° C (176° F) for 90-120 min (depending on the size) until meat reaches 68-70° C (154-158° F) internal temperature.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Conditioning. Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let the steam out. Flatten pork stomachs with weight and cool to 6° C (43° F) or lower. Round synthetic casings are not flattened.
df4bfc29-e0dc-4bc2-ba3c-5d5fedb77051 Storing. Clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface. Keep refrigerated.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 In separate containers cook heads and legs in water at 85° C (185° F) until the meat can be separated from the bone. Save meat stock. Spread all pieces on a flat surface to cool.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Cut head meat into ½” (12 mm) cubes.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Grind leg meat through 1/8” (3 mm) plate.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Mix all meats with salt, spices and blood together. Add some of the meat stock.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Stuff loosely into pork stomachs or large diameter synthetic casings.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Cook in water at 82° C (180° F) for 90-120 min (depending on the size) until meat reaches 68-70° C (154-158° F) internal temperature.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let the steam out. Flatten with weight and cool to 6° C (43° F) or lower.
7e5c7fa1-e419-4861-8da0-b3cfc3d19ba1 Clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface and cut off excess twine.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Cure meat. Cut beef into 1-3/4" (50 mm) chunks, mix with salt and Cure #1, pack firmly in a container, cover with a cloth and refrigerate for 72 hours. The head is usually cured for 4 days in 16° Bé (60° SAL) cure solution with sodium nitrite added. Jowls can be cured in for 4 days in 16° Bé (60° SAL) cure solution with sodium nitrite added. * see the note below.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Cook: pork heads in water at 203° F (95° C) until meat can be separated from bones. This may take from 2-4 hours. blanch jowls in a boiling water (212° F, 100° C) for 5-10 minutes. slow cook (185° F, 85° C) any connective tissue rich meat cuts (if used) until meat separates from bones. cook skins (if used) at 203° F (95° C) until soft.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Spread cooked meats on flat surface for cooling. Remove meat from bones when the cuts have cooled down enough to be handled.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 When removing meat from bones try to maintain meat size of about 1 inch (25 mm).
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Cut jowls into strips about 4 inch (10 cm) long and 1/4 inch (5 mm) wide.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Grind lean beef and any connective tissue rich meats (skins, hocks - if used) through 1/8" (2-3 mm) grinder plate. Grind the second time. You can use food processor to emulsify lean beef and any connective tissue rich meats, but you need to add a little cold water or finely crushed ice.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Mix all meats with spices.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Stuffing materials: pork stomachs or bladders, beef bungs, large diameter (4 inch) fibrous casings, butcher's twine. Stuff stomachs or bladders loosely and tie or sew the ends with twine.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Poach head cheeses at 185-194° F(85-90° C) for 90-180 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 160°F (72°C). Prick with a needle any pieces that have swum up to the surface to allow air to escape. Clear liquid should be observed when fully cooked head cheese is pricked with a needle.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface at 2-6° C (35-43° F) and let the steam out. Then flatten them with a weighted board at 37-40° F (3-4° C). Leave them undisturbed for 10-12 hours. They are done when inside temperature reaches 50-53° F (10-12° C). Do not flatten head cheese stuffed in sausage casing.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Insert stomachs or bladders for 1-2 minutes into boiling water to remove grease from the surface. (Scald the casings with hot water).
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Apply cold smoke (68-77° F, 20-25° C) for 6-12 hours. You may skip this time consuming step, however, traditionally made head cheese was smoked.
0b6bfe0f-ae21-4807-b5a8-57af9ab31731 Keep refrigerated.
f30d9904-de8b-4e0c-aa3f-8cbe0095cdb5 Place pork butt and 6 liters (6 quarts) in a pot. Bring to a boil and cook below the boiling point for about 2 hours. Place the meat on a table, reserve the stock and when the meat is cool enough to handle, remove the blade bone. Chop the meat finely. Take 3 liters (3 quarts) of the meat stock, add salt, pepper and all spices and bring to a boil.
f30d9904-de8b-4e0c-aa3f-8cbe0095cdb5 Gradually add cornmeal, stirring constantly until all is thorougly combined. The mixture should be thick enough to support a spoon standing on its own. If the mixture gets to thick, stir in more meat stock. Reduce heat and add all chopped meat and cook for an additional 15 minutes stirring occasionally.
f30d9904-de8b-4e0c-aa3f-8cbe0095cdb5 Line up shallow baking pans with waxed paper so that the ends extend over the long sides. Pour the mixture into the pans, allow to cool, cover with foil and place in refrigerator to set and become solid. Slice into 1/4 - 1/2” (6 -12 mm) slices and fry.
42a559d0-2f04-42ef-94e6-3b38c6fcb51d Place split pork heads in enough water to cover them and cook below the boiling point until meat separates easily from bones. Remove heads and place on a table to cool. Save meat stock. Remove the meat from the bones, the task is easily performed when the heads are still warm. Cover other meats with water and cook below the boiling point of water until done. Save meat stock.
42a559d0-2f04-42ef-94e6-3b38c6fcb51d Chop all meats finely.
42a559d0-2f04-42ef-94e6-3b38c6fcb51d Bring meat broth to a boil, add spices and start gradually adding the cornmeal, stirring constantly for the first 15 minutes, then reduce the heat and keep on cooking 15 minutes more until all is thorougly combined. The mixture should be thick enough to support a spoon standing on its own. If the mixture gets to thick, stir in more meat stock. Add all chopped meat and cook for an additional 15 minutes stirring occasionally.
42a559d0-2f04-42ef-94e6-3b38c6fcb51d Line up shallow baking pans with waxed paper so that the ends extend over the long sides. Pour the mixture into the pans, allow to cool, cover with foil and place in refrigerator to set and become solid. Slice into 1/4 - 1/2” (6 -12 mm) slices and fry.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Wash meats, then slow cook in a small amount of water water until soft. heads at 85°C (185°F) skins at 95°C (203°F) After cooking remove meat from heads and spread it apart on a flat surface to cool. Spread skins and let them cool. Save meat stock.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Cut meat into strips (7-10 cm, 3-4”) x (1-1.5 cm, ½-¾”). Grind boiled skins through 3 mm plate.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Add spices and 10% of the stock (left from boiling in relation to the weight of the head with the bone) to the meat and ground skins. Mix everything well together.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Stuffing materials: pork stomachs, 100 mm synthetic casings. Stuff stomach or synthetic casings loosely and tie the ends with twine.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Poach head cheeses at 82°C (180°F) for 90-150 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 68-70°C (154-158°F). Remove air with a needle from pieces that swim up to the surface.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface at 2-6°C (35-43°F) and let the steam out. Then flatten them with weight and cool them to below 6°C (43°F). If there is no proper cooler available, cool them down to less than 12°C (53°F). Do not flatten synthetic casings.
9b1d4a25-b22d-4d8d-a34b-35d9029e1cf0 After cooling, clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface, even them out and cut off excess twine.
7dc43975-faa7-4a82-94fa-3c738311a18b Place pigs feet, salt and pepper in a pot and cover with about two inches of water. Cook below the boiling point for about 2 hours or until meat separates easily from bones. Head cheese does not require much salt and a low sodium product can be made.
7dc43975-faa7-4a82-94fa-3c738311a18b Strain liquid and save for later.
7dc43975-faa7-4a82-94fa-3c738311a18b Separate meats from bones. It is easier to perform this task when meats are still warm.
7dc43975-faa7-4a82-94fa-3c738311a18b Cut meats into smaller pieces. It is easier to cut them when they are chilled.
7dc43975-faa7-4a82-94fa-3c738311a18b Now you can go two different ways: pour your souse into containers, let them sit for 2 hours at room temperature and then place in a refrigerator. Keep it there for 12 hours to give the souse time to set. stuff with a ladle into large diameter waterproof casings, clip the ends and cook in hot water below the boiling point at 185º F (about 85º C). A rough estimate will be about 20 min for each 1/2” (12 mm) of diameter of a casing. Then place at room temperature for about 2 hours for gelatin to set. Place for 12 hours into refrigerator.
c316d5a6-bc9f-41da-a257-b53196055320 Place pigs feet, salt, pepper, bay leaf and spices in a pot and cover with about two inches of water. Cover and slow cook below the boiling point for about 2 hours or until meat separates easily from bones. Strain and save meat stock for later. Separate meats from bones. It is easier to perform this task when meats are still warm.
c316d5a6-bc9f-41da-a257-b53196055320 Cut meats into smaller pieces.
c316d5a6-bc9f-41da-a257-b53196055320 Mix meats with meat stock, vinegar, spices and smashed garlic.
c316d5a6-bc9f-41da-a257-b53196055320 Now you can go two different ways: pour your sulz into containers, let them sit for 2 hours at room temperature and then place in a refrigerator. Keep it there for 12 hours to give the souse time to set. Serve in containers OR stuff with a ladle into pork stomachs or large diameter waterproof casings, tie the ends and cook in water at 85º C (185º F). Cool partially in cold water and place at room temperature for about 2 hours for gelatin to set. Place for 12 hours into refrigerator before cutting.
851fb1f1-d89f-4ca7-80de-bfe3047d7381 Boil soup vegetables (if used) in 3-4 parts of water for 20 minutes. Drain vegetables and add the liquid to meats.
851fb1f1-d89f-4ca7-80de-bfe3047d7381 Cook all meats in a little water (below boiling point) until soft. Separate meat from bones when still warm. In home production meat is usually not ground. Save meat stock for aspic. Mix all ingredients together.
851fb1f1-d89f-4ca7-80de-bfe3047d7381 Place ingredients in a suitable container, arrange vegetables and carefully pour the hot meat stock which will become aspic (jelly) when it solidifies. Let it cool at room temperature and then refrigerate.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Cover meats with a little water and boil at 90° C (194° F) until softer. You can add soup greens (celery, carrot, leek, bay leaf) to the meats for better flavor and filter the stock when done.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Remove meats and drain, filter and save the meat stock. Separate meat from bones when still warm.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Grind skins through 3 mm (1/8") plate.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Cut meats into strips and cubes.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Mix all meats with spices adding meat stock.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Stuff into 120 mm synthetic waterproof casings.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Boil at 80° C (176° F) for 150 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 154-158° F (68-70° C). This can take 120-180 minutes.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let them steam out and cool.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Roll sausages over once in a while while they are cooling off to prevent meat from collecting in one area.
869556b6-b153-4ab8-88c5-34554b097fe1 Store in refrigerator.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Boil split pork heads and all meats in a small amount of water: at 90° C (194° F) until meat can be separated from bones. You can add soup greens (celery, carrot, leek, bay leaf) to meats for better flavor. Remove meat from heads when still warm and spread apart on a flat surface to cool. Filter and save the meat stock.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Cut pork head meat into strips 1.5 x 2 cm (5/8 x 3/4") by 7-10 cm (2 x 4").
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Grind tougher meat parts and skins with 3 mm (1/8") plate.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Mix all meats with spices adding meat stock.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Stuff mixture not too tight into hog stomachs or beef bungs about 12” (30 cm) long, 8” (20 cm ) wide and 3” (8 cm) thick. Saw the ends with butchers twine. You can stuff Sulzwurst into 120 mm synthetic waterproof casings.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Boil at 80° C (176° F) for 150 min (depending on size) until the meat reaches 154-158°F (68-70°C) internal temperature.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let them steam out and cool. Then flatten pork stomachs or beef bungs with weight on top and let them cool. They are usually left undisturbed overnight. After cooling clean off any fat or jelly that accumulated on the surface and cut off the excess twine.
0847406c-d205-4afb-bb05-2228f959e441 Head cheeses stuffed in synthetic casings are not flattened with weight. It is recommended to roll them over once in a while while they are cooling off to prevent meat from collecting in one area. Store in refrigerator.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Wash meats, then slow cook in a small amount of water water until soft. heads at 85°C (185°F) skins at 95°C (203°F) After cooking remove meat from heads and spread it apart on a flat surface to cool. Spread skins and let them cool. Save meat stock.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Cut meat into strips (7-10 cm, 3-4”) x (1-1.5 cm, ½-¾”). Grind boiled skins through 3 mm plate.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Add spices and 10% of the stock (left from boiling in relation to the weight of the head with the bone) to the meat and ground skins. Mix everything well together.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Stuffing materials: pork stomachs, pork or beef bladders, 100 mm synthetic casings. Stuff stomach or synthetic casings loosely and tie the ends with twine.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Poach head cheeses at 82°C (180°F) for 90-150 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 68-70°C (154-158°F). Remove air with a needle from pieces that swim up to the surface.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc Spread head cheeses on a flat surface at 2-6°C (35-43°F) and let the steam out. Then flatten them with weight and cool them to below 6°C (43°F). If there is no proper cooler available, cool them down to less than 12°C (53°F). Do not flatten synthetic casings.
d2777f7f-6255-4072-9382-24c53b4469cc After cooling, clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface, even them out and cut off excess twine.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Blanch tongues with hot water and remove the skin.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Cut tongues into 1-1¾” (25-40 mm) cubes. Mix thoroughly with 1.0 g (1/5 tsp.) Cure #1, place in container, cover with a cloth and place in a refrigerator for 72 hours. You may skip this curing step but the tongues in your head cheese would be of a gray color instead of vivid pink.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Except liver, poach other meats in water until soft: tongues at 185º F (85º C). skins at 203º F, (95º C). jowls at 185º F (85º C).
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Cut boiled skinless dewlap into 5 mm (¼”) cubes. Dice or cut boiled pork or veal tongues into 4 cm (1¾”) cubes (They were previously cut for curing, if this step was employed). Grind boiled skins through 2-3 mm plate. Grind raw pork liver through 2-3 mm plate.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Add salt and spices to cut and ground meats and mix thoroughly with blood.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Stuff into middles or bladders loosely and sew the ends with twine. You may use large diameter waterproof casings.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Poach at 82°C (180°F) for 90-120 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 68-70°C (154-158°F). Remove air with a needle from pieces that swim up to the surface.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface at 2-6°C (35-43°F) and let the steam out. Then flatten them with weight and cool them to below 6°C (43°F).
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 After cooling clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface, even them out and cut off excess twine.
1969fb14-bafd-4268-b57a-4072a8c777a3 Store in refrigerator.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf The best quality head cheese is made from cured meats. Split heads and tongues are immersed in curing solution (salt and cure #1). The meats cured in this manner will have a beautiful red color and a longer shelf life. The fat does not contain myoglobin so it will remain white.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cure split heads, tongues, skins and back fat for 4 days in 16° Bé (60° SAL) cure solution.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf 16° Bé (60° SAL) cure solution is made by mixing 1.32 lb (598 g) salt, 4.2 oz (120 g) cure #1 and one gallon of water. Use 1/2 part (by weight) of meat to 1 part curing solution: 100 g of meat to 200 g (200 ml) curing solution.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Wash all meats in cold water. Slow boil meats at around 200° F (93° C) until meats separate from bones. Remove from the stock and spread on the table. Save the stock. Remove meat from bones when still warm.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cut heat meat into 1/2-3/4” (12-15 mm) pieces.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cut tongues into into strips.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cut fat into 1” (25 mm) cubes.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cut skins finely or grind with 1/8” (3 mm) plate.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Mix all meats together with spices and starch. Keep on mixing and start slowly adding meat stock (from boiling meats) until meat absorbs no more.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Stuff into pork stomachs or beef bungs.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Cook in water at 80° C (176° F) for about 90 minutes until meat reaches 68-70° C (154-158° F) internal temperature.
f988f4d8-1cf6-4fb1-b10f-1b9625820bcf Remove and partially cool in cold water. Place them on flat surface and press them down with boards with weights on them.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Cover meats with water and boil at 90°C (194°F) until meats are softer. Add soup greens (celery, carrot, leek, bay leaf) for better flavor and filter the stock when done.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Remove meats and drain, filter and save the meat stock.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Remove meat from hock bones. Grind the skins.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Grind all skins through 3 mm (1/8") plate.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Cut all meats into smaller pieces.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Add one packet of gelatin to wine and meat stock and mix.*
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Mix all meats with spices adding meat stock and wine.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Stuff into 120 mm synthetic waterproof casings.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Boil at 80° C (176° F) for 150 min.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Spread head cheeses on a flat surface and let them steam out and cool.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Roll sausages over once in a while while they are cooling off.
547061e4-9c9c-4528-ae00-7278f1a2ba57 Store in refrigerator.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e For best quality head cheese it is recommended to cure meats (see notes below). Place meats in boiling water but poach at 90°C (194°F) until semi-soft. Skins should be poached until soft. Spread on a flat surface for cooling.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e Cut boiled pork head meat and hearts into 1.5 cm (5/8”) strips. Take ¼ of the previously boiled skins and grind with onion through 3 mm plate. Cut remaining ¾ of skins into 5-6 mm (¼”) strips about 5-6 mm (2-3”) long.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e Mix spices thoroughly with all meats and blood.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e Stuffing materials: pork stomachs or bladders, beef bungs, large diameter (4 inch) fibrous casings, butcher's twine. Stuff stomachs or bladders loosely and tie or sew the ends with twine.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e Poach head cheeses at 85° C (185° F) for 90-180 min (depending on size) until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 68-70°C (154-158°F). Remove air with a needle from pieces that swim up to the surface.
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e Spread head cheeses on a flat surface at 2-6° C (35-43° F) and let the steam out. Then flatten them with weight and cool them to below 6° C (43° F). If there is no proper cooler available, cool them down to less than 12° C (53° F).
38750e9c-3394-4d52-aaa0-09266a01ed3e After cooling clean head cheeses of any fat and aspic that accumulated on the surface, even them out and cut off excess twine.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Place all meats with pepper, allspice and bay leaves in a pot and add enough water to over them. Cook on low heat 2 hours. Add vegetables and cook for about 60 minutes more until meats are easily separated from bones.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Drain the stock and save.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Separate meats from bones, cool, then grind with vegetables through ¼” (6 mm) plate.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Recombine ground meats and vegetables with stock, add spices and ½ vinegar and bring to boil. Taste and add more vinegar if needed.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Meat jelly: using ladle fill the bowls or jars with the mixture, let cool and then place in refrigerator. It is up to you how much jelly you want in a finished product. Before filling bowl, you may place on the bottom a slice of hard-boiled egg, carrot, lemon, green peas or fresh parsley as a decoration. When a solidified jelly is removed from the bowl and flipped over the decorations will be on top.
92aaadd9-556c-423c-8843-39d575172cea Head cheese: using ladle pour the mixture into 60-100 mm casings and cook in water at 80° C for 60 minutes. Add less stock than for jelly. Immerse in cold water for 15 minutes, then place on the table to cool. Keep in refrigerator overnight. Ready to eat when solidified.
False False
